17$Condition: Anxious$1/24/2017 9:34:51 PM$Reviewer: NunYa, 25-34 on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $3$1$3$Worked great at first.  Then my behavior got erratic (like flooring my car to 70 mph in 25 mph zones for no reason).  Started getting irritable and shaky between doses.  Realized I had gotten hooked off 1 mg, 3 times a day for a month and half.  Tried to get off it and doctors were next to useless.  Went to ER with full-blown convulsions/muscle spasms and doctor told me it was the worst case of withdrawal he had seen in 14 years, and that I would die of a heart attack, relapse and start taking it again, or become an alcoholic.  6 years later I'm still alive, drink once or twice a week, and haven't taken any benzos since the day after my ER visit.  Be safe about it, but don't listen to doctors who tell you that you have to keep taking it forever, find one who will help taper you off.  Be strong, you CAN do it, and you'll be better off for it.     
18$Condition: Muscle Spasm$1/17/2017 11:15:08 PM$Reviewer: Charlize, 13-18 on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$4$5$I was given this medicine when I was at the hospital and I was really nervous and was having kind of an anxiety attack so the doctor gave me it to calm me down. AT the time i was also at the hospital because I was having a weird right facial spasm that gave me headaches daily. The doctor gave me 2 mg when I was getting something done ,then they noticed my twitching stopped. At the time they couldn't figure out the cure for my facial spams so when they noticed that it had temporarily stopped my twitching, they were immediately intrigued and told us to take it for a bit until they find an actual cure. Later on, i have been taking 2 mg of attivan and it had made me really sleepy and it made it hard to stay away in school. Months later, they reduced the dosage to 1 mg, and it made me less sleepy but still same side effects. even though i refused to admit it, it made me forgetful, although it made me really relaxed, etc., and it did change my mood a lot based from what my family said. I would think i get headaches if i wasn't on it, I was taking it daily btw. Now coming off of it , it did have bad withdrawal symptoms my mood was completely messed up, it made me sad at times, however i was never mad, just crying but that was because i had a lot going on however i know the medicine did not totally help me either. I wouldn't say the medicine is bad because I'm pretty sure if u have anxiety and etc. this medicine would help a lot HOWEVER TAKE IN GOOD CONSIDERATION THAT THIS IS ADDICTING , AND U MIGHT BE ADDICTED AND NOT EVEN BE AWARE.

column2: 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $1$1$1$"Lorazepam nearly killed me during cancer treatment.1-2 mg/night 2 yrs. Many severe side effects unrecognized by 8 doctors in 3 hospitals. All docs seem to think safe as candy. No matter what the dose you will go through withdrawal if you stop cold turkey. You just don't know yet that you are addicted.

column1: It is prescribed to women twice as often as men. Largest group on Ativan is women over 60. Why? 1/3 of nursing home residents in the US receive a benzodiazepine. 5x increase in memory & concentration. 4x risk of daytime fatigue. 2x risk of falls and fractures of hip and wrist. 2x risk of car accident when driving. Problems with urine. Long term use slowly dulls your brain and erases your personality and sense of self. Lungs ached & felt like I had the flu for 2 years. Onco did not know the side effects of a drug she loves to prescribe without any idea of the consequences. How can this be when the information is all over the internet about the dangers of rapid withdrawal. www.benzobuddies.org may be able to help you see what you are doing to yourself with the help of your prescribing doctor. He is not helping you. Ativan is supposed to be used for only 2-4 weeks not forever. It accumulates in the brain. The older you are the more slowly your brain can process the drug. 6-18 months withdrawal physically. The longer you take it the longer it takes to get off the drug. Up to a year or more for your brain to recover if it ever does. I thought addiction meant I would want more and more. I took the med as directed so thought there was no problem. WRONG! You don't have any idea you are addicted until you try to stop. I didn't abuse this drug. This drug abused my entire brain and body. It will do the same to you. If you don't believe me watch the lorazepam withdrawal videos on youtube. More people who are suffering due to doctors' prescriptions taken faithfully. 1/3 of nursing home patients get a benzo. They give it for the dementia it causes in the first place. Why Why Why"

column10: but it relaxes him enough that he will dose off. It does not keep him asleep
column11: though - he wakes up every 2 hours or so throughout the night. We usually have to give him 2 doses about 5 hours apart. The second dose seems to have a much better effect on enabling him to sleep.  However
column12: his cardiologist now wants him off the Ativan due to the addictive side effects
column13: and has put him on Ambien to sleep instead.  The Ambien doesn't seem to do much of anything for him. I would say the Ativan is a good drug if you are keyed up
column15: simply to calm you. I doesn't seem to make my dad fuzzy headed or unable to function after he wakes up
column16: so that is good.  He is 63
column18: so perhaps the 1mg pill is too weak for a man of his size. We will try some other natural remedies to help him sleep so he doesn't need to Ativan as much.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver) $1$1$1$My mom was sent to ER after taking this drug.  She is 93 and never had to take drugs except atenolol.  She broke her ankle and needed to be confined to bed so nursing home doctor prescribed ativan as well as pain medication to keep her in bed.  Could not stay awake and started talking gibberish and was totally out of it.  We were sure she had had a stroke.  Was sent to ER where they did CAT scan and blook work.  ER physician said it was absolutely not a drug to be given to older people as it affected their balance and their brains.  Hard lesson to learn but hope this keeps others from making same mistake.  Could have killed her
column3: but she is again bright and cheery and in bed
column4: thanks to family 24-hour surveillance.

column2: 13-18 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$1$"I was initially medicated at an ER due to severe tics and panic attacks I was having due to my Tourette's.  (I was hitting myself and jerking so much it was horrible)

column1: I was giving Ativan IM injection around 10:00 at night in the ER
column2: which made me very drowsy
column3: and made my vision blurr. I recall talking about how I saw 4 doctors
column4: though I knew it was only a split in my vision.

column1: I can't remember anything after lying down on the gurney
column2: or the following day
column3: other than what I've pieced together.

column1: My parents were given a 'scrip for tablets
column2: which they had filled immediately.
we went home that night
column3: and the following day
column4: according to my parents
column5: I became very agitated
column6: to the point of physically ripping the clothing off of my body... (I'm glad I don't remember that) and clawed at myself
column7: at which point my doctor told us to go to the ER and request admission to the pychiatric unit.

column1: I didn't know what to think--I was terrified and watned to stop having these crazy movements and feel alittle calmer
column2: and stop breaking things.
I was physically restrained and given yet another dose of Ativan
column3: at which point
column4: I became delusional
column5: and believed the ER staff were cannibals whom planned to eat me.

column1: It took two days and several consultations with neurologists and psychologists to sort out the facts: I was a teenage girl with a movement disorder who had a severe psychotic reaction to Ativan....

column2: adn I went home
column3: horrified at what had happened.  Taht's not all that transpired in the ER
column4: but that's not the point.

column1: My point is this: it can do things to you.
Ativan made me psychotic.  It is very rare
column2: but it has happened
column3: and doctors may not always recognize this."

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $2$1$1$"to those who think this is NOT addictive
column3: I say haha...try running out of the stuff for a few days & see how you feel.  I rely on a mail-order service for my prescriptions & my Ativan refill was ""lost in the mail"" for a week.  During the dreadful cold turkey stage I gradually got numb & trembling extremities and trembling lower jaw.  I was convinced I had Lou Gehrigs Disease; I was convinced that if I got in my car to go to the ER I would get in an accident & die also.  Finally called a friend to take me to ER where they gave me a shot of Ativan & a temporary supply to last until my refill arrived.  It doesn't help my anxiety at all but I can't stop taking it due to the horrible withdrawl side effects.  "

column1: 387$Condition: Anxious$3/30/2010 4:12:04 AM$Reviewer:  Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more$5$5$5$"I have been on Lorezapam (generic for Ativan) for about 12 years now. I have stopped taking it for periods of time (up to 3 months or more)

392$Condition: Anxious$3/27/2010 9:06:38 AM$Reviewer: Bob, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$5$5$I originally started on this medication back in 1985 when it was given to me for panic attacks - I tried several other drugs before ativan (including the various anti depressant drugs, all of which did nothing except produce terrible side effects) and none of them worked - ativan worked immediately and I have been on it ever since - at one point, I was taking 6mgs per day and am now on a regular dose of 1mg. I have to laugh at all the medical experts who warn against long term use of ativan (and similar medications) suggesting patients will require larger and larger doses for effect when the exact opposite has been the case for me - the only side effect I experience is the relief of anxiety. I am now in excellent health, do not suffer from panic attacks nor any anxiety beyond the usual day to day stress, and wouldn't hesitate to recommend this medication to anyone given my experience. I would rate it a class A medication in all respects!

45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $2$1$3$Anyone that is thinking of using ativan - don't. Anyone that is using it now -beware.  I was an ativan user for 4yrs. It was a nightmare. Of course it worked in the beginning
column3: but after awhile it stopped working.  I started with xanax then went to klonipin then ativan. What a mistake. For extreme anxiety it started to work. Er visits started to increase. I started having a lot of stomach pains
column4: chest pains
column5: and leg pains. Most important was that I felt like a zombie all the time. I wasn't leaving the house and  sunshine bothered my eyes. I just couldn't function outside of the home. I finally had the courage to take control of my own life and decided to admit myself to a hospital detox unit. You cannot do this yourself. I tried. I've been off ativan for 2 1/2 years and I'm doing much better. My NEW md has me on lamical. I'm taking vacations
column6: moved into a new house
column7: gardening
column8: put in a pool. I'm not totally free of the withdrawal yet but I'm still hanging in there and enjoying life. Exercise does help and I've joined two classes. Hint- walking outside helps a lot
column9: drink plenty of water(helps with anxiety) breathing & relaxation music is a must. Remember- ativan is very addicting. My diagnosis was that it was slowing killing me. I DO STRUGGLE EVERYDAY BUT NOW I'M IN CONTROL NOT THE ATIVAN--IT DID IT'S DAMAGE ON ME. Ativan puts a block in your brain so you don't feel the anxiety which makes you feel like you are in a waking coma. If I can help at least one person by my experience then it was worth it. Please don't use ativan -it slowly kills.

562$Condition: Chronic Trouble Sleeping$6/29/2009 5:39:03 PM$Reviewer: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$4$5$I am a three time cancer survivor and I have terrible neurapathy in my feet and legs caused by the chemo to treat my cancer.  My chemo was 5 years ago and the painful neurapathy has never went away.  It keeps me awake at night and I can barely stand the pain during the day hours.  I have been taking lorazapam now for 5 years just to sleep and get any relief I can from the constant burning and tingling in my feet and legs.  I am also trying lyrica with the lorazapam and I get some added pain relief but have fears of becoming addicted to these drugs.  Insurance Co's give me a hard time about pre-existing conditions but I figure they can't possibly understand the constant pain I am in.  It's terrible!!!!!! I survived cancer but I am left with pain and uncaring people at the insurance co.  I hope I will be able to keep taking these medications as my husband has lost his job and has been unable to find a new one now for more than a year.  Keep me in your prayers.  My opinion on this drug is that it all I have.  Has done alot of good for me and I would recommend it for people with painful chemo neurapathy.
563$Condition: Anxious$6/29/2009 4:39:55 PM$Reviewer: Bob, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$1$5$Gave me serious double vision.

column4: it is addictive and taken with alcohol or after alcohol in any frequency is a recipe for disaster.  I used it for ""hangovers"" because it ""helped""
column5: and it did just that
column6: but wait
column7: Get into that cycle and coming off puts people in a serious world of hurt.  Be Safe

column1: Ativan is a good drug ONLY when taken at small doses and when absolutely needed
column2: otherwise try meditation or something less scary to stop."

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $1$1$5$"be very careful taking this drug. i was prescribed to take 1mg twice a day for 1 week and only when needed after that. it worked wonders for that 1 week. after stopping for a few days the ""benzodiazepine withdraw syndrome"" (look it up on Wikipedia) set in. Almost every symptom listed set in. i saw 5 gp doctors and 2 specialist and not one said anything about the withdraw. i was told to keep taking them until i almost killed myself and after hours and hours of research i discovered what i was going through. i have been off of them for a little over a week and the nightmare seems to be subsiding a lttle each day. i was a healthy active person that happened to have a so called panic attack out of the blue in January and it has been a terror ride ever since."

I went back told him I was off the lexapro it wasn't working anymore and the ativan did a lot better He asked if I had trouble stopping the lexaprox any side affects I was a little jumpy I was on it for 3 yrs so he went for 2months than 10days off. When I went back this time I told him I had no problem with just quitting Ativan no side effects nothing. He gave me a scrip for 90 days. I wean myself off at times just don't sleep good when I do. This works for me sleep good at night my depression is better and it is CHEAP not like the fancy lexapro.Doc let me have the 90days with refills if I promise him I would stop for a week or so than start again if I had problems stopping call him I am going to continue to take it if I get addicted so be it. I am still better off than I was. I am 71yrs so I have been here a while. Alcohol and gambling are gone that saves me a bundle. I think ativan if there is such a thing is the all in one drug. I quess I will contiue to go off and then back on. Still don't know why you can't just keep on it.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$" Fantastic drug when used in moderation! Not to be used if genetically inclined to be addicted to anything esp. drugs! Started Ativan when I had a ""screamer"" of a boss. Thought I was just a ""Drama Queen"" while venting my opinions. I thought I was verbalizing for everyone who wouldn't. I swore profusely & rationalized it by calling myself jokingly ""Tammy Tourette"" (as in the syndrome.) However
column3: all my co-workers were indeed stressed but did not ""dramatize"" it as I did.  I went to the Doctor. He diagnosed me with borderline high anxiety and prescribed Ativan. It saved me profusely. Took 1mg at that job(waitress at very busy place.) Was fantastic! Realized I am only one person that can only do what I can do. I want to make everyone happy--Really!

column1: Have now used Ativan off & on for 4 years. No side effects (can take at 2a.m. for insomnia & go to Jazzercise @8:30am) & feel wonderful & go to work standing for 8-hours
column2: lifting
column3: walking
column4: people pleasing
column5: all day. Only side effect for me is that it takes away my stressfully induced ""humor"" which everyone knows me for. But it such a relief to take a break! For them & me!

column1: It's so funny that I'm so paranoid about becoming addicted to a high-anxiety drug that works so well for me. Use it when you need it only. Like taking the sleeper airfare to your destination. Or going to Europe when the jet-lag will kill you the first 3-days. Or going on a job interview. This drug works for that!!"

column3: which is sometimes desired (as opposed to remaining awake and suffering ).  Be careful not to drive after taking this medicine
column4: however
column5: because it has a similar effect on the brain as alcohol (I am not sure of the Chemistry behind that statement
column6: but that is what I have been told by psychiatrists and pharmacists.)  Great short-acting benzo
column7: but highly addictive
column8: so be very careful.  Do not abuse it
column9: and be cautious when coming off of it - make sure you do not precipitously stop taking it b/c there could be serious withdrawal symptoms.  Just be careful with it and it will work wonders (in the short term).  Try Klonopin for a longer acting benzo...

column4: it is meant for short term use (2-3) weeks. The doctors tell you that
column5: they do not
column6: however
column7: tell you what can happen if you take for a long period of time. I have been taking Lorazepam for 6 years
column8: 1 mg/twice a day. Prior to that I was on Xanax for 10 years.I have now become tolerant and am having withdrawal symptoms. I have done quite a bit of research on this and withdrawal can last years or even decades. This drug needs to be tapered off VERY slowly for a minimum of about 10 months. Some people have terrible withdrawal symptoms for years after stopping this medication. It messes with the Gaba receptors in your brain as well as your central nervous system. Read the Ashton Manual. Doctors keep prescribing these types of drugs because they are getting kickbacks from 'Big Pharma' to do so. Do your research and get off this horrible drug if you have been on for a long time.

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$4$5$I've been taking this drug for over a year
column3: 1mg right before bedtime for anxiety/insomnia.  I have had stressful sleep for years and have a really hard time staying asleep due to anxiety.  I'd rather have 5 hours a night of good sleep vs. 8 hours of stressful sleep.  It's like not sleeping at all.  The doctor said I need to take 1mg at night before bedtime to sleep well.  She said that taking it just once a day will not cause physical addiction because the half life is 12 hours.  So she said it's important to break that 12 hour cycle up to prevent physical addiction.  She said if I take it for a long time
column4: less than 12 hours apart
column5: apparently that's when you can get physically addicted.  The doctor said I may end up psyhologically addicted
column6: but that's easy to kick shortly after I stop taking it.  1mg an hour before I want to go to sleep works absolutely great.  I haven't slept so good since I was a kid.  The doctor said that the only real side effects from this drug are addiction
column7: and it's very important to get good sleep or I'll end up with other problems
column8: like high blood pressure
column9: heart problems
column10: kidney problems
column11: increased stress
column12: etc.  So I feel any possible side effects of long term use of this drug is probably worth it.  I feel great
column13: am probably healthier overall from it
column14: and can get more out of life now that I don't have to walk around like a sleepless zombie all day.

1383$Condition: Chronic Trouble Sleeping$4/10/2010 11:44:50 AM$Reviewer: Lily in Boston, 55-64 Female  (Patient) $3$3$5$I've been taking Lorazepam (or Ativan) for two years for menopausal insomnia.  Of all the drugs I've tried, it has been the most helpful with the least side effects. I try not to take it every night and go off it for months at a time. It was most effective when I first started taking it; I quickly developed a tolerance and needed a higher dose which I didn't want to take so I just continued to take .5 or less. I generally take .25. It does help me fall asleep and wake up less often and sleep more soundly.  It only makes me a little groggy and the withdrawal symptoms when I stop taking it have been minimal--headache and slightly shaky feeling. I don't like being dependent on any drug but it's better than not sleeping! There are times when it's been a great relaxant and stress reliever.

45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$5$5$"It take it for episodic panic attacks and general bouts of anxiety. It seems particularly valuable in situations where my anxiousness is so great that I am unable to concentrate at work. It calms me considerably thus allowing me to be more productive.

column1: However there is a trade off. My mental acuity is not as sharp and it gives me the feeling of being slightly intoxicated. Not surprisingly it lowers my energy level and makes me feel slightly sleepy. Yet still a good trade off versus a panic freeze that makes me completely dysfunctional. Also I've discover that it is best to use the smallest dose possible that will still allow me to derive the benefit without experiencing the hazy side effects. I often break the one milligram pill in half or even quarters.
I try never to use it more than 2 days in a row for fear of addiction.
I also use it at night for insomnia that results from racing mind syndrome. Used in conjunction with ambien
column2: I never fails to get me to sleep and usually sleep 8 hours or more. (Wouldn't suggest this for those who have any side effects with ambien). I do have a slight hang over effect from the lorazepam which makes it hard to hit the ground running in the morning
column3: but not as bad as the hangover you get from a night of drinking.

column2: I've had a good experience... and it certainly has saved many a day I would have otherwise just been pacing the floor... wringing my hands over an anxiety attack. "

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $5$5$5$I have bad panic attacks to the point i feel like im going to die. I went to the ER thinking i was going to die. They gave me a shot in my IV and i only remember a few stupid things i asked the nurse. I loved this drug and would get it again if i had that bad of an attack. The only thig is you say really embassing things and can't remember much for about a good 6 hours for me anyway. I would recomend this for panic attacks.
